column4: So I've been trying to use dd with the following command (in bold): dd if=/ of/tempdir/disk.iso but for some reason it doesn't write anything, do I need to dismount the OS to perform DD?
The if argument needs to be a file or a block device, not a directory.
And you should be *very* careful with dd, if you get something wrong you could whipe out all the data on your hard drive.
I understand it operates at the block level, but when I do /dev/simfs I get this (in bold): dd: opening `/dev/simfs': Operation not permitted
What is the output of "lsb_release -d"?
Please pastebin the output of "mount".
Please follow my directions, I'd like to see the complete output of the command "mount", no more, less, or different.
And please use http://pastebin.ubuntu.com .
Sure thing, it won't be any different than what I just told you though :)
Please follow my instructions exactly. I asked you for the output of "mount".
my bad, here ya go: http://pastebin.ubuntu.com/1371855/
You have a very odd configuration because this is a hosted container, not a default Ubuntu install.
yeah, as soon as I am done with this I'm gonna kiss that host good-bye

There is no real block device associated with symfs, it just maps files in your container to files in the host's filesystem. To do a block level copy you'd need to be able to access the host's hard drive (which also contains the files for all of the other containers on that machine).
In other words, dd is not an option for you.

OK that makes more sense to me now, I'm not familiar with SimFS.  Basically I'm trying to move files from a OpenVZ VPS system to my dedicated server where I have created a Guest VirtualBox VM  (All machines are Ubuntu 12.04LTS Server x64).  Should I just rsync / to / ?
You can do that, just know that there are probably a lot of configuration files that contain settings specific to OpenVZ containers, since that's what the system you're using now is.
rsync is the way to go, if you really want to copy everything. Though after the rsync your new "copied" system will probably fail to boot until you remove the OpenVZ specific stuffs.
Could I ask my hosting company to go onto their OpenVZ server and create a raw disk image of my VPS server for me?
There is no raw disk to image, your container is just a collection of files in a directory.
Exactly.
